children.name: to say that you think sb has done sth bad
allege c2
children.definition: allege to saypubliclythat sb has done sthbadorillegal, even though this has not been proved -used especially in newspapers and news reports:tố cáo
examples: allege that
in a statement to the press, massey alleged that her husband had planned to kill her.
be alleged to have done sth
taylor is alleged to have used public money to buy expensive presents for her friends.
it is alleged that
it has been alleged that senior officials were involved in a $20 million drugs deal.
alleged[attri] c1
when questioned about the alleged incident, he claimed to know nothing.
allegedly[adv]c2
prosecutors have arrested johnson for allegedly accepting bribes from a property developer.
a gang of merseyside men were allegedly involved in smuggling £500,000-worth of cannabis.
allegation[c usually plural] c1 a public statement saying that someone has done something bad or illegal, even though this has not been proved:
make an allegation
the newspaper made several allegations, none of which turned out to be true.
allegation of
there were allegations of corruption in the police department.
allegation about
the book contains shocking allegations about the senator’s private life.
allegation that
there have been allegations in the press that the fire was started deliberately.
serious allegation
these are serious allegations. do you have any evidence to support them?
deny an allegationsay it is false
weimar denied allegations of financial mismanagement.

children.name: confront c2
children.definition: confront to accuse someone of doing something by showing them the proof against them: cho đối chất
examples: confront sb with the evidence/proof etc
the fbi confronted schmidt with the evidence of his part in the murder plot.

children.name: accuse b2
children.definition: accuse to say that sb is guilty of doing something bad: buộc tội
examples: they’re accusing me without any proof.
accuse sb of
are you accusing her of lying?
protesters angrily accused the police of violence and intimidation.
accusation[c] c1 a statement saying that someone has done something bad:sự buộc tội
make an accusation
you’ve made a lot of accusations but you haven’t come up with any evidence to support them.
accusation against
a spokesman said the accusations against mr fallon would be investigated.accusation of.
there have been accusations of racism in the los angeles police department.
level an accusation against sb/sthformal make an accusation :
a number of accusations have been levelled against hutchinson by his former colleagues.
wild accusationan accusation made without thinking carefully first : cáo buộc dại dột
you shouldn’t make any wild accusations if you’re not absolutely sure that wilkins stole the money.
accusing[attri]cáo buộc
‘where have you been?’ mick asked in an accusing tone of voice.
accusingly[adv] if you look at, point at, or speak to sb accusingly, you do it in a way that shows you think they have done something bad:
janet suddenly pointed at me, and everyone looked at me accusingly.
‘you did it, tom,’ she said accusingly. ‘i know you didn’t mean to, but you did do it.’

children.name: point the finger at x
children.definition: point the finger at/ˌpɔɪnt ðə ˈfɪŋgər æt/  to say that you think someone is probably responsible for something bad that has happened, although you do not have definite proof:
examples: ▪ someone’s lost the letter and the boss is pointing the finger at me. ai đó đã mất lá thư và ông chủ chỉ ngón tay vào tôi.

children.name: blame b1
children.definition: blame/bleɪm/  to say or think that someone is responsible for somethingbadthat hashappened: khiển trách, đổ lỗi
examples: ▪ it’s your idea - don’t blame me if it doesn’t work.
đó là ý tưởng của cậu - đừng đổ lỗi cho tôi nếu nó không có hiệu quả
▪ everyone wants to blame the referees when their team loses.
mọi người đều muốn đổ lỗi cho trọng tài khi đội của họ thua
blame sb for something: đổ lỗi cho ai đã làm việc gì
▪ democrats have blamed republicans for the failure to reach an agreement.
đảng dân chủ đã đỗi lỗi cho đảng cộng hòa khi không thể đàm phán
blame sth on somebody/something: đổ lỗi chuyện gì lên ai
▪ some of the women blamed their husbands’ violence on drinking.
vài người phụ nữ cho rằng bạo lực từ chồng của họ là do việc uống rượu
blame yourself: tự trách
▪ for many years i blamed myself for her death.
nhiều năm rồi tôi vẫn luôn tự trách nhiệm về cái chết của cô ấy

children.name: put the blame on b2
children.definition: put/lay/place the blame on  to say who you think is responsible for somethingbadthat hashappened, oftenunfairlyorwrongly:đổ lỗi cho
examples: ▪ don’t try to put the blame on me! đừng có đổ lỗi cho tôi
▪ subsequent investigations placed the blame squarely on city officials.
put/lay the blame for sth on sb/sth
▪ farmers have laid the blame for their problems entirely on eu policies.

children.name: say sth is sb's fault b1
children.definition: say it’s somebody’s fault/ˌseɪ ɪts somebodyˈs ˈfɔːlt/  especiallyspokento say that someone is responsible for something bad that has happened:
examples: đổ lỗi cho ai
▪ everyone is saying it’s my fault, but i didn’t have anything to do with it.
mọi người đều đang đổ lỗi cho tôi, nhưng tôi chẳng có dính líu gì tới nó cả
say it’s sb’s fault (that): đổ lỗi cho ai rằng
▪ how can you say it’s my fault that you lost your job?
làm sao mà anh có thể nói đó là lỗi của tôi khi mà anh mất việc?

children.name: apportion blame x
children.definition: apportion blame formal to officially say which people are responsible for something bad that has happened: "chia phần" trách nhiệm
examples: ▪ it is not easy for the committee of inquiry to apportion blame in such a complicated case.
không dễ để mà ủy ban điều tra có thể tuyên bố được trách nhiệm là thuộc về ai trong một trường hợp phức tạp như vậy

children.name: hold sb responsible x
children.definition: hold sb responsible to say that it is sb’s fault that sth bad has happened because you think it was their duty to prevent this from happening : đổ trách nhiệm cho ai
examples: ▪ it’s your decision - you can’t hold me responsible if it goes wrong.
hold sb responsible for:đổ lỗi/trách nhiệm cho ai trong việc gì
▪ alex still holds his mother responsible for the divorce.
hold sb partly/largely/entirely responsible:
▪ the shipment never arrived, and we are holding the freight company entirely responsible.
hold somebody personally responsibleblame one person only:
▪ if anything happens to donny, i’ll hold you personally responsible.

children.name: reproach yourself c2
children.definition: reproach yourself/rɪˈprəʊtʃ jɔːʳˌself/  to feel that something is your fault and wish that you had done more to prevent it from happening: tự trách mình
examples: ▪ there’s no point in reproaching yourself - there’s nothing you could have done.
có tự trách mình cũng vô ích - anh không thể làm được gì cả.
reproach yourself for. tự trách mình vì chuyện gì
▪ he reproached himself for not having called the police sooner.
anh ta tự trách mình khi đã không gọi cảnh sát sớm hơn

children.name: shoot the messenger x
children.definition: shoot the messenger/ˌʃuːt ðə ˈmesndʒəʳ/  to become angry at someone who tells you bad news even though they are not responsible for what has happened : bắn người đưa tin
examples: if you don’t listen and instead shoot the messenger, you’re not going to learn about the problems you need to deal with.

children.name: to be blamed for sth, especially unfairly
get the blame b2
children.definition: get the blame/ get blamed to be blamed for sth, especially something that you did not do: bị đổ lỗi
examples: ▪ hurry up! it’s me who’ll get the blame if we’re late.
▪ the crowds cause the problems, but the police get blamed for it.
get the blame/get blamed for
▪ television often gets blamed for the decline in family life.
get the blame/get blamed for doing sth
▪ karen got blamed for losing the deal.

children.name: take the blame b2
children.definition: take the blame/ˌteɪk ðə ˈbleɪm/  to accept that people will blame you for something, either because it is your fault or because they think it is your fault: chịu trách nhiệm
examples: ▪ the coach took the blame for his team’s loss.
take the blame for
▪ my wife didn’t want me to take the blame for something we were both involved in.
▪ i took the blame for butch because i was afraid of him.

children.name: be in the firing line
children.definition: if a person, group, or organization is in the firing line, they arepubliclyblamed for something bad that has happened because people think they areofficiallyresponsible:bị chỉ trích, khiển trách ( công khai bởi rất nhiều người )
examples: rail bosses are in the firing line again following last week’s accident.
trimble may find himself on the firing line for not responding to the escalating violence.

children.name: take the rap x
children.definition: take the rap/ˌteɪk ðə ˈræp/  informal to be blamed and punished for a crime or a mistake, even if you did not do it: chịu phạt
examples: ▪ i’m not going to take the rap for management’s mistakes.
take the rap for
▪ the police will make sure someone takes the rap for this, and they don’t care who it is

children.name: carry the can x
children.definition: carry the can britishinformalto be theonlypersonblamed and punished for something that is someone else’s faultas well as your own:gánh trách nhiệm
examples: ▪ alan’s senior colleagues decided to let him carry the can.
carry the can for
▪ as chairman i was left to carry the can for a decision that made no sense and was not of my doing.

children.name: take the fall x
children.definition: take the fall us to be blamed and punished for amistakeor acrime, even if you did not do it:chịu trách nhiệm
examples: he won’t go to jail, he’ll get one of his associates to take the fall.
take the fall for
if you think i’m going to take the fall for the scandal just to protect the senator, you’re crazy.

children.name: sb who is unfairly blamed for sth
scapegoat x
children.definition: scapegoat/ˈskeɪpgəʊt/  sb who is unfairly blamed or punished for something, because people want to see that someone is blamed or punished for it: kẻ bị trách oan, người chịu đạn thay
examples: ▪ the captain was just a scapegoat. the real villains were the people in charge of the shipping company.
▪ the public is looking for a scapegoat, but no one will be accused until a full inquiry has been held

children.name: fall guy x
children.definition: fall guy/ˈfɔːl gaɪ/  especially american someone who ispunishedfor someone else’s crime or mistake, because people have deliberately made it look as if he or she is responsible:
examples: người chịu phạt oan,người chịu đạn thay
▪ journalists asked if the secretary of state was going be the fall guy for the president’s secret arms deal.
các nhà làm báo đã hỏi rằng liệu bộ trưởng ngoại giao hoa kì sẽ thất bại trong hợp đồng mua bán vũ khí bí mật của ngài tổng thống
▪ benson made it clear he does not intend to be the fall guy.
beson khăng khăng rằng anh ta sẽ không chịu tội giúp ai

children.name: to blame sb else for sth that is your fault
shift the blame b2
children.definition: shift the blame đổ lỗi , đẩy trách nhiệm
examples: shift the blame onto
you can’t always shift the blame onto your secretary.
shift the blame for
lawyers for the doctor have tried to shift the blame for the child’s death onto the parents.

children.name: pass the buck x
children.definition: pass the buckinformalto try to blame someone else for a problemat workthat you are responsible for:đổ trách nhiệm ( 1 vấn đề trong công việc )
examples: you were in charge of that project, so don’t try to pass the buck.
pass the buck to
it was his mistake but he tried to pass the buck to another manager.

children.name: to prove that sb should not be blamed
exonerate x
children.definition: exonerate/ clear toofficiallyshow that someone who has been blamed for something is not in fact responsible for it.exonerateis more formal thanclear:miễn tội, miễn trách nhiệm
examples: ▪ simmons was tried and cleared of all charges.
▪ false accusations were made, but he was eventually exonerated.

children.name: recriminations x
children.definition: recriminations/rɪˌkrɪmɪˈneɪʃənz, rɪˌkrɪməˈneɪʃənz/  a situation in which people are blaming each other: sự tố cáo lẫn nhau, đổ lỗi cho nhau
examples: ▪ family life had become unbearable for her - the arguments, the recriminations, the accusations - so she left.
▪ smith’s widow and son have traded recriminations since his death in august.

children.name: implication c2
children.definition: implicationnoun sự dính líu hoặc bị dính líu (nhất là vào một tội ác)
examples: [ u ] when you suggest or show that someone is involved in a crime
_the case depended upon his implication of his co-workers in the fraud.
